abstract.text: An application shortcut item, also called a Home Screen dynamic quick action, that specifies a user-initiated action for your app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: On a device that supports 3D Touch, a person invokes the quick action by pressing your app’s icon on the Home Screen and then selecting the quick action’s title. Your app delegate receives and handles the quick action.
You must specify the characteristics of your
instances during initialization, before you register them with your app object. The quick actions you’ve registered with your app object are immutable.

content.text: Register an array of dynamic quick actions with your app

inlineContent.text: To register an array of Home Screen dynamic quick actions, set the value of your shared app object’s
property with an
instance containing your defined dynamic Home Screen quick actions.

content.text: Change your app’s dynamic quick actions

inlineContent.text: To change your app’s Home Screen dynamic quick actions, replace your app object’s
array by setting a new value for the property. As a convenience for working with registered quick actions, this class has a mutable subclass,
. The following code snippet illustrates one way to use the
method, along with mutable quick actions, to change the title of a dynamic Home Screen quick action:

code: guard let mutableShortcutItem = existingShortcutItem.mutableCopy() as? UIMutableApplicationShortcutItem

inlineContent.text: Although immutable, a
instance is considered
dynamic
to distinguish it from a
static
quick action you specify at build time.
Define Home Screen
dynamic
quick actions using this class. Your code creates dynamic quick actions, and registers them with your app object, at runtime.
Define Home Screen
static
quick actions in the
array in your Xcode project’s
file, as described in the
chapter in
. The system registers your static quick actions when your app is installed.

The system limits the number of quick actions displayed when a user presses a Home Screen app icon. Within the limited set of displayed quick action titles, your static quick actions are shown first, starting at the topmost position in the list. If your static items don’t consume the permissible number for display and you’ve also defined dynamic quick actions using this class, then one or more of your dynamic quick actions is displayed.

content.text: App launch and app update considerations for quick actions

inlineContent.text: When a user chooses one of your Home Screen quick actions, the system launches or resumes your app and UIKit calls the
method in your app delegate. Be sure to read the description of that method in
for information on how to ensure the method is called only when it should be.

After a user first installs your app and before they first launch it, pressing your Home Screen icon displays only the app’s static quick actions. After first launch, your dynamic quick actions (if you’ve defined any and there’s room in the list to accommodate them) are displayed as well.

If a user installs an update for your app but hasn’t yet launched the update, pressing your Home Screen icon shows the dynamic quick actions for the previously installed version. One way to gracefully handle this scenario is to provide app version information in the
dictionary of a quick action.

abstract.text: An object representing a static ordered collection, for use instead of an  constant in cases that require reference semantics.
Returns the object returned by  where the zone is `nil`.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
The Home screen dynamic quick actions for your app; available on devices that support 3D Touch.
A set of methods to manage shared behaviors for your app.
Tells the delegate that the user selected a Home screen quick action for your app, except when you’ve intercepted the interaction in a launch method.
An image you can optionally associate with a Home Screen quick action to improve its appearance and usability.
An application shortcut item, also called a Home Screen dynamic quick action, that specifies a user-initiated action for your app.
The optional icon for the Home Screen dynamic quick action.
Creates an immutable Home Screen dynamic quick action with a user-visible title and no icon.
Creates an immutable Home Screen dynamic quick action with user-visible title, icon, and user info dictionary.
The optional, user-visible subtitle for the Home Screen dynamic quick action.
The required, user-visible title for the Home Screen dynamic quick action.
The object that determines which scene handles the quick action.
A required, app-specific string that you employ to identify the type of quick action to perform.
Optional, app-specific information that you can provide for use when your app performs the Home screen quick action.
A mutable Home Screen dynamic quick action, which is an item that specifies a configurable user-initiated action for your app.
Expose commonly used functionality with static or dynamic 3D Touch Home Screen quick actions.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
A protocol that mutable objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
